Two interesting heterobimetallic coordination polymers (CPs), {[Ni(4-pytpy)2]2[Cu4(N(CN)2)7](NO3)(DMF)(DMSO)(H2O)4}n (1) and {[Co(4-pytpy)(N(CN)2)]2[Cu2(N(CN)2)4]}n (2), have been synthesized based on different metalloligands [M(4-pytpy)2]2+ (M=Ni 1, Co 2) (4-pytpy = 4′-(4-pyridyl)-2,2′:6′,2″-terpyridine). CPs 1 and 2 have been well characterized by elemental analysis, IR spectroscopy, thermal analysis and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Both CPs 1 and 2 crystallize in the triclinic crystal system with the P-1 space group but feature different structures. CP 1 exhibits a unique one dimensional double-chain structure, while CP 2 possesses an infinite 2D network structure. It is interesting to note that the metalloligand [Co(4-pytpy)2]2+ in CP 2 was decomposed into [Co(4-pytpy)]2+. Thermal analysis indicates that the chain structure of CP 1 begins to collapse after about 360 °C, while CP 2 can be stable up to 300 °C. The solid-state luminescence properties of CPs 1 and 2 have also been investigated.

Introduction

Coordination polymers (CPs), which are usually built from metal cations/clusters with organic linkers, have attracted considerable attention because of their interesting topological structures and potential applications in material science [1–5]. Although a large number of CPs have been reported during the past two decades, it is still difficult for researchers in this field to rationally design and synthesize CPs with precise architectures and desired properties [6–9]. In recent years, the application of metalloligands as precursors has been regarded as an applicable strategy to the construction of CPs [10]. For example, the metalloligands [MS4]2− (M=W, Mo) and [M(CN)8]3−/4− (M=W, Mo, Nb) have been widely used to synthesize CPs with fascinating topological structures and novel properties, such as non-liner optical and magnetic properties [10–16]. Recently, the metalloligands [M(4-pytpy)2]2+ (M=Ru, Fe, Ni, Co) based on ligand 4-pytpy (4′-(4-pyridyl)-2,2′:6′,2″-terpyridine, see Scheme 1) have been explored as ideal precursors for the syntheses of heterobimetallic CPs [14–16]. Beves and his coworkers have reported several one-dimensional heterobimetallic CPs with good stability and hyperconjugation, which were obtained from the reaction of metalloligands [M(4-pytpy)2]2+ (M=Ru, Fe) and Ag+ ions [14, 16]. However, the application of such metalloligands [M(4-pytpy)2]2+ as precursors for the design and syntheses of heterobimetallic CPs with various molecular configurations and applicable physical functions still remains largely unexplored [17].

On the other hand, the final structures and properties of CPs are also influenced by many factors, such as the auxiliary ligands, polarity of solvent, and the counterions [18, 19]. Among these factors, the auxiliary ligand always plays an important role in the fabrication of CPs. For instance, the N-containing ligands and carboxylic acids have been widely used in the construction of CPs. As a typical nitrogen ligand, the anion [N(CN)2]− is a flexible auxiliary ligand with multiple coordination sites and different coordination geometries. It has been documented that many CPs based on [N(CN)2]− show interesting electrical, magnetic properties or nonlinear optical properties [20–22].

In the present study, by applying the metalloligands [M(4-pytpy)2]2+ (M=Ni, Co) and the auxiliary ligand [N(CN)2]−, two interesting heterobimetallic CPs {[Ni(4-pytpy)2]2[Cu4(N(CN)2)7](NO3)(DMF)(DMSO)(H2O)4}n (1) and {[Co(4-pytpy)(N(CN)2)]2[Cu2(N(CN)2)4]}n (2) have been prepared and well characterized. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis shows that CP 1 features a unique 1D double-chain structure, which is built by metalloligands [Ni(4-pytpy)2]2+ connected with [Cu4(N(CN)2)7]3− cluster units alternately. CP 2 possesses an infinite 2D network structure, which is constructed by 1D {[Co(4-pytpy)(N(CN)2)]+}n cationic cluster chains linked through [Cu2(N(CN)2)4]2− cluster units. Thermal analysis indicates that the chain structure of CP 1 begins to collapse after about 360 °C, while the network of CP 2 can be stable up to 300 °C. Solid-state luminescence properties of both CPs 1 and 2 have also been investigated.

Experimental SectionMaterials and Methods

All the reagents were obtained commercially and used without further purification except specifically mentioned. The ligand 4′-(4-pyridyl)- 2,2′:6′,2″-terpyridine (4-pytpy) and the metalloligands [M(4-pytpy)2](NO3)2 (M=Ni, Co) were prepared according to the literatures [23, 24]. The elemental analysis for C, H, and N was performed on a FLASH 1112A micro-analyzer. The IR spectra (4000–400 cm−1) were recorded by a Nicolet Nexus 470 transform spectrometer with samples prepared as KBr pellets. The thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed in N2 atmosphere from 25 to 1200 °C for CPs 1 and 2 by a NETZSCH STA 449F3 system with a heating rate of 10 °C/min. The solid-state luminescence spectra were collected at room temperature under a QuantaMaster & TimeMaster Spectrofluorometer system.

Synthesis of {[Ni(4-pytpy)<sub>2</sub>]<sub>2</sub>[Cu<sub>4</sub>(N(CN)<sub>2</sub>)<sub>7</sub>](NO<sub>3</sub>)(DMF)(DMSO)(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>4</sub>}<sub>n</sub> 1

The addition of [Ni(4-pytpy)2](NO3)2 (0.05 mmol, 0.0402 g) in 2 mL DMSO solution resulted in a light yellow solution. After stirring and subsequent filtration, a solution of DMSO (3 mL) was layered gently on the top of the filtrate. After that, a solution of CuN(CN)2 (0.2 mmol,0.0261 g) and NaN(CN)2 (0.2 mmol,0.0178 g) dissolved in 2 mL DMF/CH3CN (v/v = 1:1) was successively laid carefully as the third layer. The resulting solution was allowed to diffuse slowly in the dark. After 1 week, orange needle crystals of CP 1 were obtained for single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. Yield: 0.035 g, 59.3 %. Anal. Calc. for C99H77Cu4N39Ni2O9S (%): C, 50.32; H, 3.26; N, 23.13; Found: C, 50.28; H, 3.25; N, 23.15. IR for CP 1 (KBr pellets, cm−1): 3456(m), 3065(m), 2364(m), 1609(s), 1492(m), 1385(vs), 1016(m), 809(m).

Synthesis of {[Co(4-pytpy)(N(CN)<sub>2</sub>)]<sub>2</sub>[Cu<sub>2</sub>(N(CN)<sub>2</sub>)<sub>4</sub>]}<sub>n</sub> 2

CP 2 was obtained as brown needle crystals by the same procedure as that of CP 1, except that the same amount of [Ni(4-pytpy)2](NO3)2 were replaced by [Co(4-pytpy)2](NO3)2. Yield: 0.028 g, 88.8 %. Anal. Calc. for C52H28Co2Cu2N26 (%): C, 49.45; H, 2.20; N, 28.84; Found: C, 49.41; H, 2.19; N, 28.87. IR (KBr pellets, cm−1): 3056(m), 2067(vs), 1603(s), 1411(s), 1249(s), 782(s).

Crystal Structure Determination

Suitable single crystals of CPs 1 and 2 were selected and mounted in air onto thin glass fibers. The diffraction data were measured with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71,070 Å) on a Rigaku Saturn724+ CCD diffractometer. The SMART and SAINT program packages were used for data collection and integration, respectively. Collected data were corrected for absorbance using SADABS based upon Laue symmetry using equivalent reflections. All structures were solved by direct methods and refined on F2 by full-matrix least-squares calculations with the use of SHELX-97 program package [25]. All of non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal displacement coefficients. Hydrogen atoms on the carbon atoms were introduced in calculated positions with isotopic thermal parameters using a riding model approximation. The molecular plots were obtained using Olex2 program [26]. Significant crystallographic data are summarized in Table 1.

Results and DiscussionSyntheses and IR Spectra

Both CPs 1 and 2 were assembled from the reaction of metalloligands [M(4-pytpy)2](NO3)2 (M=Ni, Co), CuN(CN)2 and NaN(CN)2 in a ratio of 1:4:4 under the mixed solvent edge-diffusion method [13]. However, in contrast to [Ni(4-pytpy)2]2+ that induced the conformation of CP 1, the starting metalloligand [Co(4-pytpy)2]2+ was decomposed into [Co(4-pytpy)]2+ in the synthetic process of CP 2. Additional experiments with different concentrations of [Co(4-pytpy)2](NO3)2 were explored to elucidate the synthetic process, and it demonstrated that CP 2 can also be obtained through other synthetic recipes, including the reactant ratios of [Co(4-pytpy)2]2+/Cu+/[N(CN)2]− in 1:2:2, 1:1:1, and 2:1:1. The follow-up experiments also indicate that the appearance of new metalloligand [Co(4-pytpy)]2+ present in the 2D skeleton of CP 2 has nothing to do with the molar ratios of the reactants. In particular, the bridged ligand [N(CN)2]− in metalloligand [Co(4-pytpy)(N(CN)2)] of CP 2 connects both Co1 and Co2 atoms, not only serving as an electron-donor ligand but may also playing an important role in achieving the unique 2D network of CP 2. This may therefore imply that the different metalloligands ([Ni(4-pytpy)2] in 1 and [Co(4-pytpy)(N(CN)2)] of 2) separately induced the conformation of 1D double-chain structure of CP 1 and 2D network skeleton of CP 2 (see Scheme 2).

The IR spectra of 4-pytpy ligand and CPs 1–2 are recorded with samples prepared as KBr pellets (Fig. S3). For 4-pytpy ligand and CPs 1–2, the ν(C–H) vibration of benzene ring is observed around 3000–3100 cm−1 [27]. The peak at 1581 cm−1 may be attributed to the vibrations of C=N bond in 4-pytpy ligand, while the stretching vibrations near 1600 cm−1 belong to ν(C=N) in CPs 1 and 2, which confirms the retention of C=N bond and the coordination of 4-pytpy ligand to the metals [27]. The IR band near 2360 cm−1 can be assigned to ν(C≡N) vibrations of the μ3-bridged [N(CN)2]− ligand in CP 1, while the peak at 2050 cm−1 belongs to ν(C≡N) vibrations of the μ2-bridged [N(CN)2]− ligand for CP 2, respectively [28]. The presence of [NO3]− anion in CP 1 is attested by the appearance of strong absorption peak at 1385 cm−1 [29]. Moreover, CP 1 shows a broad band at 3456 cm−1, confirming the O–H stretch of the free H2O molecules [29]. The IR spectra of CPs 1 and 2 are in good agreement with the results of the X-ray structural analysis, which were described in detail as follows.

Crystal Structure of 1

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis shows that CP 1 crystallizes in the triclinic crystal system with P-1 space group and exhibits a unique 1D double-chain structure. The asymmetric unit of CP 1 contains two cationic metalloligands [Ni(4-pytpy)2]2+, one anionic cluster unit [Cu4(N(CN)2)7]3–, one [NO3]− anion, one free DMF solvent molecule, one free DMSO solvent molecule and four free H2O molecules (Fig. S1).

The coordination modes of Ni and Cu atoms in CP 1 are depicted in Fig. 1. As shown in Fig. 1a, the Ni atom is coordinated by six N atoms from two 4-pytpy ligands, forming a distorted octahedral configuration. The Cu atom has three different coordination environments: Cu1 atom is coordinated by two terminal N atoms from two [N(CN)2]− ligands and one N atom from the cationic metalloligand [Ni(4-pytpy)2]2+ (Fig. 1b); both Cu2 and Cu3 atoms are associated by two terminal N atoms from two [N(CN)2]– ligands, one central N atom from one [N(CN)2]− ligand and one N atom from the metalloligand [Ni(4-pytpy)2]2+ (Fig. 1c); Cu4 atom is coordinated by three terminal N atoms from three [N(CN)2]− ligands and one N atom from the metalloligand [Ni(4-pytpy)2]2+ (Fig. 1d).

The selected crystallographic parameters of CPs 1 and 2 are listed in Table 2. For CP 1, the values of Cu1–N bond lengths range from 1.898(4) to 1.992(4) Å with a mean value of 1.935(7) Å, while the bond angles of N–Cu1–N fall in the range of 115.55(2)°–122.38(2)°. The average bond length of Cu4–N is 2.012(4) Å and the N–Cu4–N bond angles are in the range of 94.58(2)°–125.8(2)°. Although the Cu2 and Cu3 atoms have the same coordination modes, the values of Cu–N bond lengths and the N–Cu–N bond angles for the Cu2 and Cu3 atoms are different: the average Cu2–N distances is 2.061(4) Å, which is shorter than the mean value of Cu3–N bond lengths (2.085(4) Å), while the bond angles of N–Cu2–N and N–Cu3–N fall in the range of 94.82(2)°–122.28(2)° and 94.36(2)°–123.85(2)°, respectively. The difference of Cu–N bond lengths and N–Cu–N bond angles between Cu2 and Cu3 atoms can be attributed to the different steric environments around the Cu atoms [30, 31].

As in Fig. 2a, the cationic metalloligands [Ni(4-pytpy)2]2+ are connected with anionic cluster units [Cu4(N(CN)2)7]3−, which is formed by Cu atoms linked with the [N(CN)2]− ligands, to construct the 1D infinite double-chain extended approximately toward c axis. Interestingly, the [N(CN)2]− ligand in CP 1 shows two different kinds of coordination modes. Owing to the μ3-bridged mode of [N(CN)2]− ligand, linking between two Cu2 and Cu3 atoms leads to a distorted pseudo quadrangular configuration (Fig. 2b). The bridging ligands [N(CN)2]− are also involved in a large six-membered (Cu–Ni–Cu–Cu–Ni–Cu) hexagon ring geometry, which is constructed by two [N(CN)2]-bridged units connecting with two metalloligands [Ni(4-pytpy)2]2+ (Fig. 2c). These two kinds of rings are further connected alternately to form the 1D chain structure of CP 1. As in Fig. 3, packing structure of CP 1 contains several distorted elliptical channels, which can be filled with the solvent molecules.

Crystal Structure of 2

The crystallographic analysis reveals that CP 2 also crystallizes in the triclinic system with P-1 space group, and is constructed by metalloligand [Co(4-pytpy)]2+, Cu atoms, and [N(CN)2]− bridges to form a 2D network structure (Fig. 5c). The asymmetric unit of CP 2 contains two cationic metalloligands [Co(4-pytpy)]2+, two [N(CN)2)]– ligands and one anionic cluster unit [Cu2(N(CN)2)4]2− (Fig. S2).

The coordination modes of Co and Cu atoms in CP 2 are described in Fig. 4. As displayed in Fig. 4a, there are two kinds of Cu atoms in CP 2: Cu1 atom is coordinated by three N atoms from three [N(CN)2]− ligands and one N atom from the 4-pytpy ligand, while Cu2 atom is coordinated by two N atoms from two [N(CN)2]− ligands and one N atom from 4-pytpy ligand. However, the coordinated environments for two Co atoms are almost similar in this 2D skeleton (Fig. 4b). Both Co1 and Co2 atoms are coordinated by three N atoms from 4-pytpy ligand and two terminal N atoms from two [N(CN)2]− ligands, forming the distorted trigonal bipyramid geometry. The Co1 atom is connected with two Co2 atoms through two [N(CN)2]− ligands and one Cu2 atom via the 4-pytpy ligand, while the Co2 atom is linked with two Co1 atoms and one Cu1 atom.

In CP 2, the average bond length of Cu1–N (2.021(3) Å) is little shorter than the mean value of Cu2–N bond (2.113(3) Å), while the bond angles of N–Cu1–N and N–Cu2–N fall in the range of 99.17(1)°–123.19(1)° and 93.31(1)°–128.30(1)°, respectively. For Co1 and Co2 with similar coordination modes, there are only a little bit differences between the bond lengths of Co1–N and Co2–N and the bond angles of N–Co1–N and N–Co2–N: the Co1–N bond lengths fall in the range of 1.938(3)–2.213(3) Å, whereas the distances between Co2 and N atoms range from 1.939(3) to 2.224(3) Å; the bond angles of N–Co–N are in the range of 78.88(1)°–161.67(1)° for Co1 and 79.70(1)°–161.29(1)° for Co2.

The [N(CN)2]– ligand coordinates with both Cu1 and Cu2 atoms giving rise to an anionic cluster unit [Cu2(N(CN)2)4]2− (Fig. 5a), while the metalloligand [Co(4-pytpy)]2+ connects with [N(CN)2]− ligands alternately to form a 1D chain structure (Fig. 5b). These neighboring 1D chains are further linked through the anionic cluster units [Cu2(N(CN)2)4]2− to construct a unique 2D network structure (Fig. 5c). From the view of topology, the Co atoms can be regarded as the 3-connected nodes, while [N(CN)2]− ligands and [Cu2(4-pytpy)2(N(CN)2)]+ cluster units can accordingly act as the sides. Therefore, the 2D network of CP 2 can be defined as a 3-connected topology with point symbol as 63 (Fig. 6). The neighboring packing structures of CP 2 can be seen as two combs meshing with each other along [110] direction (Fig. 7).

Thermal Analysis

Thermal properties of CPs 1 and 2 were evaluated by thermogravimetric analysis under the N2 atmosphere from 25 to 1200 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min. It is worth noting that the structure of CP 1 begins to collapse after about 360 °C, while the network of CP 2 begins to collapse at around 300 °C. This thermal behavior of CPs 1 and 2 is in sharp contrast to that of monometallic CPs based on 4-pytpy ligand, which usually starts to collapse near 180 °C [29].

As described in Fig. 8, the TGA curve of CP 1 can be divided into three stages. The first weight loss of 8.61 % occurs in 95–219 °C, corresponding to the liberation of free H2O molecules, DMF and volatiles of NO3– (NO2, O2) (calculated: 3.05 % for H2O, 3.09 % for DMF and 2.63 % for NO2, O2) [32–35]. In the temperature of 341–359 °C, the second weight loss of 3.36 % is in accordance with the loss of DMSO molecules (calculated: 3.31 %). With the increase in temperature, the dicyanamide and 4-pytpy ligand begin to decompose, and the structure of CP 1 begins to collapse [35]. For CP 2, the structure is stable up to about 300 °C, followed by the weight loss of 21.13 %, which is consistent with the decomposition of four dicyanamide (calculated: 20.92 % for four dicyanamide) [35]. As the temperature increases, the 4-pytpy ligand and the rest of dicyanamide begin to decompose and the network of CP 2 continues to collapse.

Luminescent Properties

It is well-documented that CPs, especially with d10 metal centers and conjugated organic ligands, have been investigated for photoluminescent properties because of their potential applications as luminescent materials [6, 36–39]. The solid-state photoluminescence of CPs 1 and 2 was determined at room temperature, as shown in Fig. 9. The fluorescent emission peaks were observed at 468 nm (λex = 360 nm) for CP 1 and 471 nm (λex = 360 nm) for CP 2, respectively. In order to understand the nature of such emission bands, the photoluminescent property of free 4-pytpy ligand was also measured. Upon excitation at 320 nm, the free 4-pytpy ligand shows the fluorescent emission band at 374 nm, which can be assigned to the π* → π or n → π* electronic transitions (Fig. S4, Supplementary Material). In comparison with that of free 4-pytpy ligands, the observed red-shift of the emissions is probably caused by the collaborative effects of intra-ligand emission and ligand-to-metal charge transition (LMCT) [40]. The differences in the band positions of CPs 1 and 2 might be related to the differences in the metal centers and coordination environments or the degree of π-electron overlap of the multitopic organic linkers in these structures [41]. The intensity differences between CPs 1 and 2 may be ascribed to the different conjugation effect of 4-pytpy and M atom in CPs 1 and 2 [42].

Conclusions

In summary, two interesting heterobimetallic CPs have been synthesized under the assistance of the metalloligands [M(4-pytpy)2](NO3)2 (M=Ni, Co) and auxiliary ligand [N(CN)2]−. Structural analysis demonstrates that CP 1 exhibits a 1D double chain structure, while CP 2 possesses a unique 2D network skeleton. Thermal analysis reveals that the structure of CP 1 begins to collapse after about 360 °C, while CP 2 can be stable up to 300 °C. In addition, solid-state luminescence properties of CPs 1 and 2 were also investigated. The emission are red-shift for both CPs 1 and 2 in contrast to that of 4-pytpy ligand. Further studies on the design and syntheses of metalloligand-based heterobimetallic CPs with unique molecular configurations and strong luminescence properties are currently in progress.

elements.clean_text: ]>This XML was provided by Springer Naturedoi:10.1007/s10876-016-1027-631aa4ebcea41b6792ab66adebe5119a0/kaist-api111011087610.1007/10876.1572-8862Journal of Cluster ScienceIncluding Nanoclusters and NanoparticlesJ Clust Sci1040-72781572-8862Springer USNew Yorks10876-016-1027-6102710.1007/s10876-016-1027-6Original PaperMetalloligand-induced Synthesis of Two Cu(I)-M (M=Ni, Co) Heterobimetallic Coordination Polymers: Structures, Thermal and Luminescence PropertiesWeiHongyang1HuangWenjiang1QianJun2cZhangChi13d1grid.410579.e0000000091169901School of Chemical Engineering, Institute of Molecular Engineering and Advanced MaterialsNanjing University of Science and Technology210094NanjingPeople's Republic of China2grid.440785.a000000010743511XChina-Australia Joint Research Center for Functional Molecular Materials, Scientific Research AcademicJiangsu University212013ZhenjiangPeople's Republic of China3grid.258151.a0000000107081323China-Australia Joint Research Center for Functional Molecular Materials, School of Chemical and Material EngineeringJiangnan University214122WuxiPeople's Republic of Chinacjunqian8203@ujs.edu.cndchizhang@njust.edu.cnchizhang@jiangnan.edu.cn30520169201627515371552265201619320163052016© Springer Science+Business Media New York 20162016AbstractTwo interesting heterobimetallic coordination polymers (CPs), {[Ni(4-pytpy)2]2[Cu4(N(CN)2)7](NO3)(DMF)(DMSO)(H2O)4}n (1) and {[Co(4-pytpy)(N(CN)2)]2[Cu2(N(CN)2)4]}n (2), have been synthesized based on different metalloligands [M(4-pytpy)2]2+ (M=Ni 1, Co 2) (4-pytpy = 4'-(4-pyridyl)-2,2':6',2"-terpyridine). CPs 1 and 2 have been well characterized by elemental analysis, IR spectroscopy, thermal analysis and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Both CPs 1 and 2 crystallize in the triclinic crystal system with the P-1 space group but feature different structures. CP 1 exhibits a unique one dimensional double-chain structure, while CP 2 possesses an infinite 2D network structure. It is interesting to note that the metalloligand [Co(4-pytpy)2]2+ in CP 2 was decomposed into [Co(4-pytpy)]2+. Thermal analysis indicates that the chain structure of CP 1 begins to collapse after about 360 °C, while CP 2 can be stable up to 300 °C. The solid-state luminescence properties of CPs 1 and 2 have also been investigated.KeywordsHeterobimetallic coordination polymerMetalloligandAuxiliary ligandCrystal structureLuminescenceMinistry of article (doi:10.1007/s10876-016-1027-6) contains supplementary material, which is available to authorized users.IntroductionCoordination polymers (CPs), which are usually built from metal cations/clusters with organic linkers, have attracted considerable attention because of their interesting topological structures and potential applications in material science [1-5]. Although a large number of CPs have been reported during the past two decades, it is still difficult for researchers in this field to rationally design and synthesize CPs with precise architectures and desired properties [6-9]. In recent years, the application of metalloligands as precursors has been regarded as an applicable strategy to the construction of CPs [10]. For example, the metalloligands [MS4]2- (M=W, Mo) and [M(CN)8]3-/4- (M=W, Mo, Nb) have been widely used to synthesize CPs with fascinating topological structures and novel properties, such as non-liner optical and magnetic properties [10-16]. Recently, the metalloligands [M(4-pytpy)2]2+ (M=Ru, Fe, Ni, Co) based on ligand 4-pytpy (4'-(4-pyridyl)-2,2':6',2"-terpyridine, see Scheme 1) have been explored as ideal precursors for the syntheses of heterobimetallic CPs [14-16]. Beves and his coworkers have reported several one-dimensional heterobimetallic CPs with good stability and hyperconjugation, which were obtained from the reaction of metalloligands [M(4-pytpy)2]2+ (M=Ru, Fe) and Ag+ ions [14, 16]. However, the application of such metalloligands [M(4-pytpy)2]2+ as precursors for the design and syntheses of heterobimetallic CPs with various molecular configurations and applicable physical functions still remains largely unexplored [17].On the other hand, the final structures and properties of CPs are also influenced by many factors, such as the auxiliary ligands, polarity of solvent, and the counterions [18, 19]. Among these factors, the auxiliary ligand always plays an important role in the fabrication of CPs. For instance, the N-containing ligands and carboxylic acids have been widely used in the construction of CPs. As a typical nitrogen ligand, the anion [N(CN)2]- is a flexible auxiliary ligand with multiple coordination sites and different coordination geometries. It has been documented that many CPs based on [N(CN)2]- show interesting electrical, magnetic properties or nonlinear optical properties [20-22].In the present study, by applying the metalloligands [M(4-pytpy)2]2+ (M=Ni, Co) and the auxiliary ligand [N(CN)2]-, two interesting heterobimetallic CPs {[Ni(4-pytpy)2]2[Cu4(N(CN)2)7](NO3)(DMF)(DMSO)(H2O)4}n (1) and {[Co(4-pytpy)(N(CN)2)]2[Cu2(N(CN)2)4]}n (2) have been prepared and well characterized. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis shows that CP 1 features a unique 1D double-chain structure, which is built by metalloligands [Ni(4-pytpy)2]2+ connected with [Cu4(N(CN)2)7]3- cluster units alternately. CP 2 possesses an infinite 2D network structure, which is constructed by 1D {[Co(4-pytpy)(N(CN)2)]+}n cationic cluster chains linked through [Cu2(N(CN)2)4]2- cluster units. Thermal analysis indicates that the chain structure of CP 1 begins to collapse after about 360 °C, while the network of CP 2 can be stable up to 300 °C. Solid-state luminescence properties of both CPs 1 and 2 have also been investigated.Experimental SectionMaterials and MethodsAll the reagents were obtained commercially and used without further purification except specifically mentioned. The ligand 4'-(4-pyridyl)- 2,2':6',2"-terpyridine (4-pytpy) and the metalloligands [M(4-pytpy)2](NO3)2 (M=Ni, Co) were prepared according to the literatures [23, 24]. The elemental analysis for C, H, and N was performed on a FLASH 1112A micro-analyzer. The IR spectra (4000-400 cm-1) were recorded by a Nicolet Nexus 470 transform spectrometer with samples prepared as KBr pellets. The thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed in N2 atmosphere from 25 to 1200 °C for CPs 1 and 2 by a NETZSCH STA 449F3 system with a heating rate of 10 °C/min. The solid-state luminescence spectra were collected at room temperature under a QuantaMaster & TimeMaster Spectrofluorometer system.Synthesis of {[Ni(4-pytpy)2]2[Cu4(N(CN)2)7](NO3)(DMF)(DMSO)(H2O)4}n 1The addition of [Ni(4-pytpy)2](NO3)2 (0.05 mmol, 0.0402 g) in 2 mL DMSO solution resulted in a light yellow solution. After stirring and subsequent filtration, a solution of DMSO (3 mL) was layered gently on the top of the filtrate. After that, a solution of CuN(CN)2 (0.2 mmol,0.0261 g) and NaN(CN)2 (0.2 mmol,0.0178 g) dissolved in 2 mL DMF/CH3CN (v/v = 1:1) was successively laid carefully as the third layer. The resulting solution was allowed to diffuse slowly in the dark. After 1 week, orange needle crystals of CP 1 were obtained for single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. Yield: 0.035 g, 59.3 %. Anal. Calc. for C99H77Cu4N39Ni2O9S (%): C, 50.32; H, 3.26; N, 23.13; Found: C, 50.28; H, 3.25; N, 23.15. IR for CP 1 (KBr pellets, cm-1): 3456(m), 3065(m), 2364(m), 1609(s), 1492(m), 1385(vs), 1016(m), 809(m).Synthesis of {[Co(4-pytpy)(N(CN)2)]2[Cu2(N(CN)2)4]}n 2CP 2 was obtained as brown needle crystals by the same procedure as that of CP 1, except that the same amount of [Ni(4-pytpy)2](NO3)2 were replaced by [Co(4-pytpy)2](NO3)2. Yield: 0.028 g, 88.8 %. Anal. Calc. for C52H28Co2Cu2N26 (%): C, 49.45; H, 2.20; N, 28.84; Found: C, 49.41; H, 2.19; N, 28.87. IR (KBr pellets, cm-1): 3056(m), 2067(vs), 1603(s), 1411(s), 1249(s), 782(s).Crystal Structure DeterminationSuitable single crystals of CPs 1 and 2 were selected and mounted in air onto thin glass fibers. The diffraction data were measured with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71,070 Å) on a Rigaku Saturn724+ CCD diffractometer. The SMART and SAINT program packages were used for data collection and integration, respectively. Collected data were corrected for absorbance using SADABS based upon Laue symmetry using equivalent reflections. All structures were solved by direct methods and refined on F2 by full-matrix least-squares calculations with the use of SHELX-97 program package [25]. All of non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal displacement coefficients. Hydrogen atoms on the carbon atoms were introduced in calculated positions with isotopic thermal parameters using a riding model approximation. The molecular plots were obtained using Olex2 program [26]. Significant crystallographic data are summarized in Table 1.Results and DiscussionSyntheses and IR SpectraBoth CPs 1 and 2 were assembled from the reaction of metalloligands [M(4-pytpy)2](NO3)2 (M=Ni, Co), CuN(CN)2 and NaN(CN)2 in a ratio of 1:4:4 under the mixed solvent edge-diffusion method [13]. However, in contrast to [Ni(4-pytpy)2]2+ that induced the conformation of CP 1, the starting metalloligand [Co(4-pytpy)2]2+ was decomposed into [Co(4-pytpy)]2+ in the synthetic process of CP 2. Additional experiments with different concentrations of [Co(4-pytpy)2](NO3)2 were explored to elucidate the synthetic process, and it demonstrated that CP 2 can also be obtained through other synthetic recipes, including the reactant ratios of [Co(4-pytpy)2]2+/Cu+/[N(CN)2]- in 1:2:2, 1:1:1, and 2:1:1. The follow-up experiments also indicate that the appearance of new metalloligand [Co(4-pytpy)]2+ present in the 2D skeleton of CP 2 has nothing to do with the molar ratios of the reactants. In particular, the bridged ligand [N(CN)2]- in metalloligand [Co(4-pytpy)(N(CN)2)] of CP 2 connects both Co1 and Co2 atoms, not only serving as an electron-donor ligand but may also playing an important role in achieving the unique 2D network of CP 2. This may therefore imply that the different metalloligands ([Ni(4-pytpy)2] in 1 and [Co(4-pytpy)(N(CN)2)] of 2) separately induced the conformation of 1D double-chain structure of CP 1 and 2D network skeleton of CP 2 (see Scheme 2).The IR spectra of 4-pytpy ligand and CPs 1-2 are recorded with samples prepared as KBr pellets (Fig. S3). For 4-pytpy ligand and CPs 1-2, the ν(C-H) vibration of benzene ring is observed around 3000-3100 cm-1 [27]. The peak at 1581 cm-1 may be attributed to the vibrations of C=N bond in 4-pytpy ligand, while the stretching vibrations near 1600 cm-1 belong to ν(C=N) in CPs 1 and 2, which confirms the retention of C=N bond and the coordination of 4-pytpy ligand to the metals [27]. The IR band near 2360 cm-1 can be assigned to ν(C≡N) vibrations of the μ3-bridged [N(CN)2]- ligand in CP 1, while the peak at 2050 cm-1 belongs to ν(C≡N) vibrations of the μ2-bridged [N(CN)2]- ligand for CP 2, respectively [28]. The presence of [NO3]- anion in CP 1 is attested by the appearance of strong absorption peak at 1385 cm-1 [29]. Moreover, CP 1 shows a broad band at 3456 cm-1, confirming the O-H stretch of the free H2O molecules [29]. The IR spectra of CPs 1 and 2 are in good agreement with the results of the X-ray structural analysis, which were described in detail as follows.Crystal Structure of 1Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis shows that CP 1 crystallizes in the triclinic crystal system with P-1 space group and exhibits a unique 1D double-chain structure. The asymmetric unit of CP 1 contains two cationic metalloligands [Ni(4-pytpy)2]2+, one anionic cluster unit [Cu4(N(CN)2)7]3-, one [NO3]- anion, one free DMF solvent molecule, one free DMSO solvent molecule and four free H2O molecules (Fig. S1).The coordination modes of Ni and Cu atoms in CP 1 are depicted in Fig. 1. As shown in Fig. 1a, the Ni atom is coordinated by six N atoms from two 4-pytpy ligands, forming a distorted octahedral configuration. The Cu atom has three different coordination environments: Cu1 atom is coordinated by two terminal N atoms from two [N(CN)2]- ligands and one N atom from the cationic metalloligand [Ni(4-pytpy)2]2+ (Fig. 1b); both Cu2 and Cu3 atoms are associated by two terminal N atoms from two [N(CN)2]- ligands, one central N atom from one [N(CN)2]- ligand and one N atom from the metalloligand [Ni(4-pytpy)2]2+ (Fig. 1c); Cu4 atom is coordinated by three terminal N atoms from three [N(CN)2]- ligands and one N atom from the metalloligand [Ni(4-pytpy)2]2+ (Fig. 1d).The selected crystallographic parameters of CPs 1 and 2 are listed in Table 2. For CP 1, the values of Cu1-N bond lengths range from 1.898(4) to 1.992(4) Å with a mean value of 1.935(7) Å, while the bond angles of N-Cu1-N fall in the range of 115.55(2)°-122.38(2)°. The average bond length of Cu4-N is 2.012(4) Å and the N-Cu4-N bond angles are in the range of 94.58(2)°-125.8(2)°. Although the Cu2 and Cu3 atoms have the same coordination modes, the values of Cu-N bond lengths and the N-Cu-N bond angles for the Cu2 and Cu3 atoms are different: the average Cu2-N distances is 2.061(4) Å, which is shorter than the mean value of Cu3-N bond lengths (2.085(4) Å), while the bond angles of N-Cu2-N and N-Cu3-N fall in the range of 94.82(2)°-122.28(2)° and 94.36(2)°-123.85(2)°, respectively. The difference of Cu-N bond lengths and N-Cu-N bond angles between Cu2 and Cu3 atoms can be attributed to the different steric environments around the Cu atoms [30, 31].As in Fig. 2a, the cationic metalloligands [Ni(4-pytpy)2]2+ are connected with anionic cluster units [Cu4(N(CN)2)7]3-, which is formed by Cu atoms linked with the [N(CN)2]- ligands, to construct the 1D infinite double-chain extended approximately toward c axis. Interestingly, the [N(CN)2]- ligand in CP 1 shows two different kinds of coordination modes. Owing to the μ3-bridged mode of [N(CN)2]- ligand, linking between two Cu2 and Cu3 atoms leads to a distorted pseudo quadrangular configuration (Fig. 2b). The bridging ligands [N(CN)2]- are also involved in a large six-membered (Cu-Ni-Cu-Cu-Ni-Cu) hexagon ring geometry, which is constructed by two [N(CN)2]-bridged units connecting with two metalloligands [Ni(4-pytpy)2]2+ (Fig. 2c). These two kinds of rings are further connected alternately to form the 1D chain structure of CP 1. As in Fig. 3, packing structure of CP 1 contains several distorted elliptical channels, which can be filled with the solvent molecules.Crystal Structure of 2The crystallographic analysis reveals that CP 2 also crystallizes in the triclinic system with P-1 space group, and is constructed by metalloligand [Co(4-pytpy)]2+, Cu atoms, and [N(CN)2]- bridges to form a 2D network structure (Fig. 5c). The asymmetric unit of CP 2 contains two cationic metalloligands [Co(4-pytpy)]2+, two [N(CN)2)]- ligands and one anionic cluster unit [Cu2(N(CN)2)4]2- (Fig. S2).The coordination modes of Co and Cu atoms in CP 2 are described in Fig. 4. As displayed in Fig. 4a, there are two kinds of Cu atoms in CP 2: Cu1 atom is coordinated by three N atoms from three [N(CN)2]- ligands and one N atom from the 4-pytpy ligand, while Cu2 atom is coordinated by two N atoms from two [N(CN)2]- ligands and one N atom from 4-pytpy ligand. However, the coordinated environments for two Co atoms are almost similar in this 2D skeleton (Fig. 4b). Both Co1 and Co2 atoms are coordinated by three N atoms from 4-pytpy ligand and two terminal N atoms from two [N(CN)2]- ligands, forming the distorted trigonal bipyramid geometry. The Co1 atom is connected with two Co2 atoms through two [N(CN)2]- ligands and one Cu2 atom via the 4-pytpy ligand, while the Co2 atom is linked with two Co1 atoms and one Cu1 atom.In CP 2, the average bond length of Cu1-N (2.021(3) Å) is little shorter than the mean value of Cu2-N bond (2.113(3) Å), while the bond angles of N-Cu1-N and N-Cu2-N fall in the range of 99.17(1)°-123.19(1)° and 93.31(1)°-128.30(1)°, respectively. For Co1 and Co2 with similar coordination modes, there are only a little bit differences between the bond lengths of Co1-N and Co2-N and the bond angles of N-Co1-N and N-Co2-N: the Co1-N bond lengths fall in the range of 1.938(3)-2.213(3) Å, whereas the distances between Co2 and N atoms range from 1.939(3) to 2.224(3) Å; the bond angles of N-Co-N are in the range of 78.88(1)°-161.67(1)° for Co1 and 79.70(1)°-161.29(1)° for Co2.The [N(CN)2]- ligand coordinates with both Cu1 and Cu2 atoms giving rise to an anionic cluster unit [Cu2(N(CN)2)4]2- (Fig. 5a), while the metalloligand [Co(4-pytpy)]2+ connects with [N(CN)2]- ligands alternately to form a 1D chain structure (Fig. 5b). These neighboring 1D chains are further linked through the anionic cluster units [Cu2(N(CN)2)4]2- to construct a unique 2D network structure (Fig. 5c). From the view of topology, the Co atoms can be regarded as the 3-connected nodes, while [N(CN)2]- ligands and [Cu2(4-pytpy)2(N(CN)2)]+ cluster units can accordingly act as the sides. Therefore, the 2D network of CP 2 can be defined as a 3-connected topology with point symbol as 63 (Fig. 6). The neighboring packing structures of CP 2 can be seen as two combs meshing with each other along [110] direction (Fig. 7).Thermal AnalysisThermal properties of CPs 1 and 2 were evaluated by thermogravimetric analysis under the N2 atmosphere from 25 to 1200 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min. It is worth noting that the structure of CP 1 begins to collapse after about 360 °C, while the network of CP 2 begins to collapse at around 300 °C. This thermal behavior of CPs 1 and 2 is in sharp contrast to that of monometallic CPs based on 4-pytpy ligand, which usually starts to collapse near 180 °C [29].As described in Fig. 8, the TGA curve of CP 1 can be divided into three stages. The first weight loss of 8.61 % occurs in 95-219 °C, corresponding to the liberation of free H2O molecules, DMF and volatiles of NO3- (NO2, O2) (calculated: 3.05 % for H2O, 3.09 % for DMF and 2.63 % for NO2, O2) [32-35]. In the temperature of 341-359 °C, the second weight loss of 3.36 % is in accordance with the loss of DMSO molecules (calculated: 3.31 %). With the increase in temperature, the dicyanamide and 4-pytpy ligand begin to decompose, and the structure of CP 1 begins to collapse [35]. For CP 2, the structure is stable up to about 300 °C, followed by the weight loss of 21.13 %, which is consistent with the decomposition of four dicyanamide (calculated: 20.92 % for four dicyanamide) [35]. As the temperature increases, the 4-pytpy ligand and the rest of dicyanamide begin to decompose and the network of CP 2 continues to collapse.Luminescent PropertiesIt is well-documented that CPs, especially with d10 metal centers and conjugated organic ligands, have been investigated for photoluminescent properties because of their potential applications as luminescent materials [6, 36-39]. The solid-state photoluminescence of CPs 1 and 2 was determined at room temperature, as shown in Fig. 9. The fluorescent emission peaks were observed at 468 nm (λex = 360 nm) for CP 1 and 471 nm (λex = 360 nm) for CP 2, respectively. In order to understand the nature of such emission bands, the photoluminescent property of free 4-pytpy ligand was also measured. Upon excitation at 320 nm, the free 4-pytpy ligand shows the fluorescent emission band at 374 nm, which can be assigned to the π* → π or n → π* electronic transitions (Fig. S4, Supplementary Material). In comparison with that of free 4-pytpy ligands, the observed red-shift of the emissions is probably caused by the collaborative effects of intra-ligand emission and ligand-to-metal charge transition (LMCT) [40]. The differences in the band positions of CPs 1 and 2 might be related to the differences in the metal centers and coordination environments or the degree of π-electron overlap of the multitopic organic linkers in these structures [41]. The intensity differences between CPs 1 and 2 may be ascribed to the different conjugation effect of 4-pytpy and M atom in CPs 1 and 2 [42].ConclusionsIn summary, two interesting heterobimetallic CPs have been synthesized under the assistance of the metalloligands [M(4-pytpy)2](NO3)2 (M=Ni, Co) and auxiliary ligand [N(CN)2]-. Structural analysis demonstrates that CP 1 exhibits a 1D double chain structure, while CP 2 possesses a unique 2D network skeleton. Thermal analysis reveals that the structure of CP 1 begins to collapse after about 360 °C, while CP 2 can be stable up to 300 °C. In addition, solid-state luminescence properties of CPs 1 and 2 were also investigated. The emission are red-shift for both CPs 1 and 2 in contrast to that of 4-pytpy ligand. Further studies on the design and syntheses of metalloligand-based heterobimetallic CPs with unique molecular configurations and strong luminescence properties are currently in progress.Supplementary MaterialCrystallographic data (excluding structure factors) for the structures in this paper have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre, CCDC, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB2 1EZ, UK. elements.content: Two interesting heterobimetallic coordination polymers (CPs), {[Ni(4-pytpy)2]2[Cu4(N(CN)2)7](NO3)(DMF)(DMSO)(H2O)4}n (1) and {[Co(4-pytpy)(N(CN)2)]2[Cu2(N(CN)2)4]}n (2), have been synthesized based on different metalloligands [M(4-pytpy)2]2+ (M=Ni 1, Co 2) (4-pytpy = 4′-(4-pyridyl)-2,2′:6′,2″-terpyridine). CPs 1 and 2 have been well characterized by elemental analysis, IR spectroscopy, thermal analysis and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Both CPs 1 and 2 crystallize in the triclinic crystal system with the P-1 space group but feature different structures. CP 1 exhibits a unique one dimensional double-chain structure, while CP 2 possesses an infinite 2D network structure. It is interesting to note that the metalloligand [Co(4-pytpy)2]2+ in CP 2 was decomposed into [Co(4-pytpy)]2+. Thermal analysis indicates that the chain structure of CP 1 begins to collapse after about 360 °C, while CP 2 can be stable up to 300 °C. The solid-state luminescence properties of CPs 1 and 2 have also been investigated.
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Two interesting heterobimetallic coordination polymers (CPs), {[Ni(4-pytpy)2]2[Cu4(N(CN)2)7](NO3)(DMF)(DMSO)(H2O)4}n (1) and {[Co(4-pytpy)(N(CN)2)]2[Cu2(N(CN)2)4]}n (2), have been synthesized based on different metalloligands [M(4-pytpy)2]2+ (M=Ni 1, Co 2) (4-pytpy = 4'-(4-pyridyl)-2,2':6',2"-terpyridine). CPs 1 and 2 have been well characterized by elemental analysis, IR spectroscopy, thermal analysis and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Both CPs 1 and 2 crystallize in the triclinic crystal system with the P-1 space group but feature different structures. CP 1 exhibits a unique one dimensional double-chain structure, while CP 2 possesses an infinite 2D network structure. It is interesting to note that the metalloligand [Co(4-pytpy)2]2+ in CP 2 was decomposed into [Co(4-pytpy)]2+. Thermal analysis indicates that the chain structure of CP 1 begins to collapse after about 360 °C, while CP 2 can be stable up to 300 °C. The solid-state luminescence properties of CPs 1 and 2 have also been investigated.

elements.content: Coordination polymers (CPs), which are usually built from metal cations/clusters with organic linkers, have attracted considerable attention because of their interesting topological structures and potential applications in material science [1–5]. Although a large number of CPs have been reported during the past two decades, it is still difficult for researchers in this field to rationally design and synthesize CPs with precise architectures and desired properties [6–9]. In recent years, the application of metalloligands as precursors has been regarded as an applicable strategy to the construction of CPs [10]. For example, the metalloligands [MS4]2− (M=W, Mo) and [M(CN)8]3−/4− (M=W, Mo, Nb) have been widely used to synthesize CPs with fascinating topological structures and novel properties, such as non-liner optical and magnetic properties [10–16]. Recently, the metalloligands [M(4-pytpy)2]2+ (M=Ru, Fe, Ni, Co) based on ligand 4-pytpy (4′-(4-pyridyl)-2,2′:6′,2″-terpyridine, see Scheme 1) have been explored as ideal precursors for the syntheses of heterobimetallic CPs [14–16]. Beves and his coworkers have reported several one-dimensional heterobimetallic CPs with good stability and hyperconjugation, which were obtained from the reaction of metalloligands [M(4-pytpy)2]2+ (M=Ru, Fe) and Ag+ ions [14, 16]. However, the application of such metalloligands [M(4-pytpy)2]2+ as precursors for the design and syntheses of heterobimetallic CPs with various molecular configurations and applicable physical functions still remains largely unexplored [17].
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Coordination polymers (CPs), which are usually built from metal cations/clusters with organic linkers, have attracted considerable attention because of their interesting topological structures and potential applications in material science [1-5]. Although a large number of CPs have been reported during the past two decades, it is still difficult for researchers in this field to rationally design and synthesize CPs with precise architectures and desired properties [6-9]. In recent years, the application of metalloligands as precursors has been regarded as an applicable strategy to the construction of CPs [10]. For example, the metalloligands [MS4]2- (M=W, Mo) and [M(CN)8]3-/4- (M=W, Mo, Nb) have been widely used to synthesize CPs with fascinating topological structures and novel properties, such as non-liner optical and magnetic properties [10-16]. Recently, the metalloligands [M(4-pytpy)2]2+ (M=Ru, Fe, Ni, Co) based on ligand 4-pytpy (4'-(4-pyridyl)-2,2':6',2"-terpyridine, see Scheme 1) have been explored as ideal precursors for the syntheses of heterobimetallic CPs [14-16]. Beves and his coworkers have reported several one-dimensional heterobimetallic CPs with good stability and hyperconjugation, which were obtained from the reaction of metalloligands [M(4-pytpy)2]2+ (M=Ru, Fe) and Ag+ ions [14, 16]. However, the application of such metalloligands [M(4-pytpy)2]2+ as precursors for the design and syntheses of heterobimetallic CPs with various molecular configurations and applicable physical functions still remains largely unexplored [17].

elements.content: On the other hand, the final structures and properties of CPs are also influenced by many factors, such as the auxiliary ligands, polarity of solvent, and the counterions [18, 19]. Among these factors, the auxiliary ligand always plays an important role in the fabrication of CPs. For instance, the N-containing ligands and carboxylic acids have been widely used in the construction of CPs. As a typical nitrogen ligand, the anion [N(CN)2]− is a flexible auxiliary ligand with multiple coordination sites and different coordination geometries. It has been documented that many CPs based on [N(CN)2]− show interesting electrical, magnetic properties or nonlinear optical properties [20–22].
elements.clean_text: On the other hand, the final structures and properties of CPs are also influenced by many factors, such as the auxiliary ligands, polarity of solvent, and the counterions [18, 19]. Among these factors, the auxiliary ligand always plays an important role in the fabrication of CPs. For instance, the N-containing ligands and carboxylic acids have been widely used in the construction of CPs. As a typical nitrogen ligand, the anion [N(CN)2]- is a flexible auxiliary ligand with multiple coordination sites and different coordination geometries. It has been documented that many CPs based on [N(CN)2]- show interesting electrical, magnetic properties or nonlinear optical properties [20-22].

elements.content: In the present study, by applying the metalloligands [M(4-pytpy)2]2+ (M=Ni, Co) and the auxiliary ligand [N(CN)2]−, two interesting heterobimetallic CPs {[Ni(4-pytpy)2]2[Cu4(N(CN)2)7](NO3)(DMF)(DMSO)(H2O)4}n (1) and {[Co(4-pytpy)(N(CN)2)]2[Cu2(N(CN)2)4]}n (2) have been prepared and well characterized. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis shows that CP 1 features a unique 1D double-chain structure, which is built by metalloligands [Ni(4-pytpy)2]2+ connected with [Cu4(N(CN)2)7]3− cluster units alternately. CP 2 possesses an infinite 2D network structure, which is constructed by 1D {[Co(4-pytpy)(N(CN)2)]+}n cationic cluster chains linked through [Cu2(N(CN)2)4]2− cluster units. Thermal analysis indicates that the chain structure of CP 1 begins to collapse after about 360 °C, while the network of CP 2 can be stable up to 300 °C. Solid-state luminescence properties of both CPs 1 and 2 have also been investigated.
elements.clean_text: In the present study, by applying the metalloligands [M(4-pytpy)2]2+ (M=Ni, Co) and the auxiliary ligand [N(CN)2]-, two interesting heterobimetallic CPs {[Ni(4-pytpy)2]2[Cu4(N(CN)2)7](NO3)(DMF)(DMSO)(H2O)4}n (1) and {[Co(4-pytpy)(N(CN)2)]2[Cu2(N(CN)2)4]}n (2) have been prepared and well characterized. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis shows that CP 1 features a unique 1D double-chain structure, which is built by metalloligands [Ni(4-pytpy)2]2+ connected with [Cu4(N(CN)2)7]3- cluster units alternately. CP 2 possesses an infinite 2D network structure, which is constructed by 1D {[Co(4-pytpy)(N(CN)2)]+}n cationic cluster chains linked through [Cu2(N(CN)2)4]2- cluster units. Thermal analysis indicates that the chain structure of CP 1 begins to collapse after about 360 °C, while the network of CP 2 can be stable up to 300 °C. Solid-state luminescence properties of both CPs 1 and 2 have also been investigated.

elements.content: All the reagents were obtained commercially and used without further purification except specifically mentioned. The ligand 4′-(4-pyridyl)- 2,2′:6′,2″-terpyridine (4-pytpy) and the metalloligands [M(4-pytpy)2](NO3)2 (M=Ni, Co) were prepared according to the literatures [23, 24]. The elemental analysis for C, H, and N was performed on a FLASH 1112A micro-analyzer. The IR spectra (4000–400 cm−1) were recorded by a Nicolet Nexus 470 transform spectrometer with samples prepared as KBr pellets. The thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed in N2 atmosphere from 25 to 1200 °C for CPs 1 and 2 by a NETZSCH STA 449F3 system with a heating rate of 10 °C/min. The solid-state luminescence spectra were collected at room temperature under a QuantaMaster & TimeMaster Spectrofluorometer system.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

All the reagents were obtained commercially and used without further purification except specifically mentioned. The ligand 4'-(4-pyridyl)- 2,2':6',2"-terpyridine (4-pytpy) and the metalloligands [M(4-pytpy)2](NO3)2 (M=Ni, Co) were prepared according to the literatures [23, 24]. The elemental analysis for C, H, and N was performed on a FLASH 1112A micro-analyzer. The IR spectra (4000-400 cm-1) were recorded by a Nicolet Nexus 470 transform spectrometer with samples prepared as KBr pellets. The thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed in N2 atmosphere from 25 to 1200 °C for CPs 1 and 2 by a NETZSCH STA 449F3 system with a heating rate of 10 °C/min. The solid-state luminescence spectra were collected at room temperature under a QuantaMaster & TimeMaster Spectrofluorometer system.

elements.content: The addition of [Ni(4-pytpy)2](NO3)2 (0.05 mmol, 0.0402 g) in 2 mL DMSO solution resulted in a light yellow solution. After stirring and subsequent filtration, a solution of DMSO (3 mL) was layered gently on the top of the filtrate. After that, a solution of CuN(CN)2 (0.2 mmol,0.0261 g) and NaN(CN)2 (0.2 mmol,0.0178 g) dissolved in 2 mL DMF/CH3CN (v/v = 1:1) was successively laid carefully as the third layer. The resulting solution was allowed to diffuse slowly in the dark. After 1 week, orange needle crystals of CP 1 were obtained for single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. Yield: 0.035 g, 59.3 %. Anal. Calc. for C99H77Cu4N39Ni2O9S (%): C, 50.32; H, 3.26; N, 23.13; Found: C, 50.28; H, 3.25; N, 23.15. IR for CP 1 (KBr pellets, cm−1): 3456(m), 3065(m), 2364(m), 1609(s), 1492(m), 1385(vs), 1016(m), 809(m).

Synthesis of {[Ni(4-pytpy)2]2[Cu4(N(CN)2)7](NO3)(DMF)(DMSO)(H2O)4}n 1

The addition of [Ni(4-pytpy)2](NO3)2 (0.05 mmol, 0.0402 g) in 2 mL DMSO solution resulted in a light yellow solution. After stirring and subsequent filtration, a solution of DMSO (3 mL) was layered gently on the top of the filtrate. After that, a solution of CuN(CN)2 (0.2 mmol,0.0261 g) and NaN(CN)2 (0.2 mmol,0.0178 g) dissolved in 2 mL DMF/CH3CN (v/v = 1:1) was successively laid carefully as the third layer. The resulting solution was allowed to diffuse slowly in the dark. After 1 week, orange needle crystals of CP 1 were obtained for single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. Yield: 0.035 g, 59.3 %. Anal. Calc. for C99H77Cu4N39Ni2O9S (%): C, 50.32; H, 3.26; N, 23.13; Found: C, 50.28; H, 3.25; N, 23.15. IR for CP 1 (KBr pellets, cm-1): 3456(m), 3065(m), 2364(m), 1609(s), 1492(m), 1385(vs), 1016(m), 809(m).

Synthesis of {[Co(4-pytpy)(N(CN)2)]2[Cu2(N(CN)2)4]}n 2

CP 2 was obtained as brown needle crystals by the same procedure as that of CP 1, except that the same amount of [Ni(4-pytpy)2](NO3)2 were replaced by [Co(4-pytpy)2](NO3)2. Yield: 0.028 g, 88.8 %. Anal. Calc. for C52H28Co2Cu2N26 (%): C, 49.45; H, 2.20; N, 28.84; Found: C, 49.41; H, 2.19; N, 28.87. IR (KBr pellets, cm-1): 3056(m), 2067(vs), 1603(s), 1411(s), 1249(s), 782(s).

elements.content: Suitable single crystals of CPs 1 and 2 were selected and mounted in air onto thin glass fibers. The diffraction data were measured with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71,070 Å) on a Rigaku Saturn724+ CCD diffractometer. The SMART and SAINT program packages were used for data collection and integration, respectively. Collected data were corrected for absorbance using SADABS based upon Laue symmetry using equivalent reflections. All structures were solved by direct methods and refined on F2 by full-matrix least-squares calculations with the use of SHELX-97 program package [25]. All of non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal displacement coefficients. Hydrogen atoms on the carbon atoms were introduced in calculated positions with isotopic thermal parameters using a riding model approximation. The molecular plots were obtained using Olex2 program [26]. Significant crystallographic data are summarized in Table 1.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure Determination

Suitable single crystals of CPs 1 and 2 were selected and mounted in air onto thin glass fibers. The diffraction data were measured with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71,070 Å) on a Rigaku Saturn724+ CCD diffractometer. The SMART and SAINT program packages were used for data collection and integration, respectively. Collected data were corrected for absorbance using SADABS based upon Laue symmetry using equivalent reflections. All structures were solved by direct methods and refined on F2 by full-matrix least-squares calculations with the use of SHELX-97 program package [25]. All of non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal displacement coefficients. Hydrogen atoms on the carbon atoms were introduced in calculated positions with isotopic thermal parameters using a riding model approximation. The molecular plots were obtained using Olex2 program [26]. Significant crystallographic data are summarized in Table 1.

Both CPs 1 and 2 were assembled from the reaction of metalloligands [M(4-pytpy)2](NO3)2 (M=Ni, Co), CuN(CN)2 and NaN(CN)2 in a ratio of 1:4:4 under the mixed solvent edge-diffusion method [13]. However, in contrast to [Ni(4-pytpy)2]2+ that induced the conformation of CP 1, the starting metalloligand [Co(4-pytpy)2]2+ was decomposed into [Co(4-pytpy)]2+ in the synthetic process of CP 2. Additional experiments with different concentrations of [Co(4-pytpy)2](NO3)2 were explored to elucidate the synthetic process, and it demonstrated that CP 2 can also be obtained through other synthetic recipes, including the reactant ratios of [Co(4-pytpy)2]2+/Cu+/[N(CN)2]− in 1:2:2, 1:1:1, and 2:1:1. The follow-up experiments also indicate that the appearance of new metalloligand [Co(4-pytpy)]2+ present in the 2D skeleton of CP 2 has nothing to do with the molar ratios of the reactants. In particular, the bridged ligand [N(CN)2]− in metalloligand [Co(4-pytpy)(N(CN)2)] of CP 2 connects both Co1 and Co2 atoms, not only serving as an electron-donor ligand but may also playing an important role in achieving the unique 2D network of CP 2. This may therefore imply that the different metalloligands ([Ni(4-pytpy)2] in 1 and [Co(4-pytpy)(N(CN)2)] of 2) separately induced the conformation of 1D double-chain structure of CP 1 and 2D network skeleton of CP 2 (see Scheme 2).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Syntheses and IR Spectra

Both CPs 1 and 2 were assembled from the reaction of metalloligands [M(4-pytpy)2](NO3)2 (M=Ni, Co), CuN(CN)2 and NaN(CN)2 in a ratio of 1:4:4 under the mixed solvent edge-diffusion method [13]. However, in contrast to [Ni(4-pytpy)2]2+ that induced the conformation of CP 1, the starting metalloligand [Co(4-pytpy)2]2+ was decomposed into [Co(4-pytpy)]2+ in the synthetic process of CP 2. Additional experiments with different concentrations of [Co(4-pytpy)2](NO3)2 were explored to elucidate the synthetic process, and it demonstrated that CP 2 can also be obtained through other synthetic recipes, including the reactant ratios of [Co(4-pytpy)2]2+/Cu+/[N(CN)2]- in 1:2:2, 1:1:1, and 2:1:1. The follow-up experiments also indicate that the appearance of new metalloligand [Co(4-pytpy)]2+ present in the 2D skeleton of CP 2 has nothing to do with the molar ratios of the reactants. In particular, the bridged ligand [N(CN)2]- in metalloligand [Co(4-pytpy)(N(CN)2)] of CP 2 connects both Co1 and Co2 atoms, not only serving as an electron-donor ligand but may also playing an important role in achieving the unique 2D network of CP 2. This may therefore imply that the different metalloligands ([Ni(4-pytpy)2] in 1 and [Co(4-pytpy)(N(CN)2)] of 2) separately induced the conformation of 1D double-chain structure of CP 1 and 2D network skeleton of CP 2 (see Scheme 2).

elements.content: The IR spectra of 4-pytpy ligand and CPs 1–2 are recorded with samples prepared as KBr pellets (Fig. S3). For 4-pytpy ligand and CPs 1–2, the ν(C–H) vibration of benzene ring is observed around 3000–3100 cm−1 [27]. The peak at 1581 cm−1 may be attributed to the vibrations of C=N bond in 4-pytpy ligand, while the stretching vibrations near 1600 cm−1 belong to ν(C=N) in CPs 1 and 2, which confirms the retention of C=N bond and the coordination of 4-pytpy ligand to the metals [27]. The IR band near 2360 cm−1 can be assigned to ν(C≡N) vibrations of the μ3-bridged [N(CN)2]− ligand in CP 1, while the peak at 2050 cm−1 belongs to ν(C≡N) vibrations of the μ2-bridged [N(CN)2]− ligand for CP 2, respectively [28]. The presence of [NO3]− anion in CP 1 is attested by the appearance of strong absorption peak at 1385 cm−1 [29]. Moreover, CP 1 shows a broad band at 3456 cm−1, confirming the O–H stretch of the free H2O molecules [29]. The IR spectra of CPs 1 and 2 are in good agreement with the results of the X-ray structural analysis, which were described in detail as follows.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis shows that CP 1 crystallizes in the triclinic crystal system with P-1 space group and exhibits a unique 1D double-chain structure. The asymmetric unit of CP 1 contains two cationic metalloligands [Ni(4-pytpy)2]2+, one anionic cluster unit [Cu4(N(CN)2)7]3–, one [NO3]− anion, one free DMF solvent molecule, one free DMSO solvent molecule and four free H2O molecules (Fig. S1).
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of 1

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis shows that CP 1 crystallizes in the triclinic crystal system with P-1 space group and exhibits a unique 1D double-chain structure. The asymmetric unit of CP 1 contains two cationic metalloligands [Ni(4-pytpy)2]2+, one anionic cluster unit [Cu4(N(CN)2)7]3-, one [NO3]- anion, one free DMF solvent molecule, one free DMSO solvent molecule and four free H2O molecules (Fig. S1).

elements.content: The coordination modes of Ni and Cu atoms in CP 1 are depicted in Fig. 1. As shown in Fig. 1a, the Ni atom is coordinated by six N atoms from two 4-pytpy ligands, forming a distorted octahedral configuration. The Cu atom has three different coordination environments: Cu1 atom is coordinated by two terminal N atoms from two [N(CN)2]− ligands and one N atom from the cationic metalloligand [Ni(4-pytpy)2]2+ (Fig. 1b); both Cu2 and Cu3 atoms are associated by two terminal N atoms from two [N(CN)2]– ligands, one central N atom from one [N(CN)2]− ligand and one N atom from the metalloligand [Ni(4-pytpy)2]2+ (Fig. 1c); Cu4 atom is coordinated by three terminal N atoms from three [N(CN)2]− ligands and one N atom from the metalloligand [Ni(4-pytpy)2]2+ (Fig. 1d).

elements.content: The selected crystallographic parameters of CPs 1 and 2 are listed in Table 2. For CP 1, the values of Cu1–N bond lengths range from 1.898(4) to 1.992(4) Å with a mean value of 1.935(7) Å, while the bond angles of N–Cu1–N fall in the range of 115.55(2)°–122.38(2)°. The average bond length of Cu4–N is 2.012(4) Å and the N–Cu4–N bond angles are in the range of 94.58(2)°–125.8(2)°. Although the Cu2 and Cu3 atoms have the same coordination modes, the values of Cu–N bond lengths and the N–Cu–N bond angles for the Cu2 and Cu3 atoms are different: the average Cu2–N distances is 2.061(4) Å, which is shorter than the mean value of Cu3–N bond lengths (2.085(4) Å), while the bond angles of N–Cu2–N and N–Cu3–N fall in the range of 94.82(2)°–122.28(2)° and 94.36(2)°–123.85(2)°, respectively. The difference of Cu–N bond lengths and N–Cu–N bond angles between Cu2 and Cu3 atoms can be attributed to the different steric environments around the Cu atoms [30, 31].

As in Fig. 2a, the cationic metalloligands [Ni(4-pytpy)2]2+ are connected with anionic cluster units [Cu4(N(CN)2)7]3−, which is formed by Cu atoms linked with the [N(CN)2]− ligands, to construct the 1D infinite double-chain extended approximately toward c axis. Interestingly, the [N(CN)2]− ligand in CP 1 shows two different kinds of coordination modes. Owing to the μ3-bridged mode of [N(CN)2]− ligand, linking between two Cu2 and Cu3 atoms leads to a distorted pseudo quadrangular configuration (Fig. 2b). The bridging ligands [N(CN)2]− are also involved in a large six-membered (Cu–Ni–Cu–Cu–Ni–Cu) hexagon ring geometry, which is constructed by two [N(CN)2]-bridged units connecting with two metalloligands [Ni(4-pytpy)2]2+ (Fig. 2c). These two kinds of rings are further connected alternately to form the 1D chain structure of CP 1. As in Fig. 3, packing structure of CP 1 contains several distorted elliptical channels, which can be filled with the solvent molecules.

Interestingly, the [N(CN)2]- ligand in CP 1 shows two different kinds of coordination modes. Owing to the μ3-bridged mode of [N(CN)2]- ligand, linking between two Cu2 and Cu3 atoms leads to a distorted pseudo quadrangular configuration (Fig. 2b). elements.content: The crystallographic analysis reveals that CP 2 also crystallizes in the triclinic system with P-1 space group, and is constructed by metalloligand [Co(4-pytpy)]2+, Cu atoms, and [N(CN)2]− bridges to form a 2D network structure (Fig. 5c). elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of 2

The crystallographic analysis reveals that CP 2 also crystallizes in the triclinic system with P-1 space group, and is constructed by metalloligand [Co(4-pytpy)]2+, Cu atoms, and [N(CN)2]- bridges to form a 2D network structure (Fig. 5c). The asymmetric unit of CP 2 contains two cationic metalloligands [Co(4-pytpy)]2+, two [N(CN)2)]- ligands and one anionic cluster unit [Cu2(N(CN)2)4]2- (Fig. S2).

elements.content: The coordination modes of Co and Cu atoms in CP 2 are described in Fig. 4. As displayed in Fig. 4a, there are two kinds of Cu atoms in CP 2: Cu1 atom is coordinated by three N atoms from three [N(CN)2]− ligands and one N atom from the 4-pytpy ligand, while Cu2 atom is coordinated by two N atoms from two [N(CN)2]− ligands and one N atom from 4-pytpy ligand. However, the coordinated environments for two Co atoms are almost similar in this 2D skeleton (Fig. 4b). Both Co1 and Co2 atoms are coordinated by three N atoms from 4-pytpy ligand and two terminal N atoms from two [N(CN)2]− ligands, forming the distorted trigonal bipyramid geometry. The Co1 atom is connected with two Co2 atoms through two [N(CN)2]− ligands and one Cu2 atom via the 4-pytpy ligand, while the Co2 atom is linked with two Co1 atoms and one Cu1 atom.

elements.content: The [N(CN)2]– ligand coordinates with both Cu1 and Cu2 atoms giving rise to an anionic cluster unit [Cu2(N(CN)2)4]2− (Fig. 5a), while the metalloligand [Co(4-pytpy)]2+ connects with [N(CN)2]− ligands alternately to form a 1D chain structure (Fig. 5b). These neighboring 1D chains are further linked through the anionic cluster units [Cu2(N(CN)2)4]2− to construct a unique 2D network structure (Fig. 5c). From the view of topology, the Co atoms can be regarded as the 3-connected nodes, while [N(CN)2]− ligands and [Cu2(4-pytpy)2(N(CN)2)]+ cluster units can accordingly act as the sides. Therefore, the 2D network of CP 2 can be defined as a 3-connected topology with point symbol as 63 (Fig. 6). The neighboring packing structures of CP 2 can be seen as two combs meshing with each other along [110] direction (Fig. 7).

elements.content: Thermal properties of CPs 1 and 2 were evaluated by thermogravimetric analysis under the N2 atmosphere from 25 to 1200 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min. It is worth noting that the structure of CP 1 begins to collapse after about 360 °C, while the network of CP 2 begins to collapse at around 300 °C. This thermal behavior of CPs 1 and 2 is in sharp contrast to that of monometallic CPs based on 4-pytpy ligand, which usually starts to collapse near 180 °C [29].
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Analysis

Thermal properties of CPs 1 and 2 were evaluated by thermogravimetric analysis under the N2 atmosphere from 25 to 1200 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min. It is worth noting that the structure of CP 1 begins to collapse after about 360 °C, while the network of CP 2 begins to collapse at around 300 °C. This thermal behavior of CPs 1 and 2 is in sharp contrast to that of monometallic CPs based on 4-pytpy ligand, which usually starts to collapse near 180 °C [29].

elements.content: As described in Fig. 8, the TGA curve of CP 1 can be divided into three stages. The first weight loss of 8.61 % occurs in 95–219 °C, corresponding to the liberation of free H2O molecules, DMF and volatiles of NO3– (NO2, O2) (calculated: 3.05 % for H2O, 3.09 % for DMF and 2.63 % for NO2, O2) [32–35]. In the temperature of 341–359 °C, the second weight loss of 3.36 % is in accordance with the loss of DMSO molecules (calculated: 3.31 %). With the increase in temperature, the dicyanamide and 4-pytpy ligand begin to decompose, and the structure of CP 1 begins to collapse [35]. For CP 2, the structure is stable up to about 300 °C, followed by the weight loss of 21.13 %, which is consistent with the decomposition of four dicyanamide (calculated: 20.92 % for four dicyanamide) [35]. As the temperature increases, the 4-pytpy ligand and the rest of dicyanamide begin to decompose and the network of CP 2 continues to collapse.

In the temperature of 341-359 °C, the second weight loss of 3.36 % is in accordance with the loss of DMSO molecules (calculated: 3.31 %). elements.content: It is well-documented that CPs, especially with d10 metal centers and conjugated organic ligands, have been investigated for photoluminescent properties because of their potential applications as luminescent materials [6, 36–39]. The solid-state photoluminescence of CPs 1 and 2 was determined at room temperature, as shown in Fig. 9. The fluorescent emission peaks were observed at 468 nm (λex = 360 nm) for CP 1 and 471 nm (λex = 360 nm) for CP 2, respectively. In order to understand the nature of such emission bands, the photoluminescent property of free 4-pytpy ligand was also measured. Upon excitation at 320 nm, the free 4-pytpy ligand shows the fluorescent emission band at 374 nm, which can be assigned to the π* → π or n → π* electronic transitions (Fig. S4, Supplementary Material). In comparison with that of free 4-pytpy ligands, the observed red-shift of the emissions is probably caused by the collaborative effects of intra-ligand emission and ligand-to-metal charge transition (LMCT) [40]. The differences in the band positions of CPs 1 and 2 might be related to the differences in the metal centers and coordination environments or the degree of π-electron overlap of the multitopic organic linkers in these structures [41]. The intensity differences between CPs 1 and 2 may be ascribed to the different conjugation effect of 4-pytpy and M atom in CPs 1 and 2 [42].
elements.clean_text:
Luminescent Properties

It is well-documented that CPs, especially with d10 metal centers and conjugated organic ligands, have been investigated for photoluminescent properties because of their potential applications as luminescent materials [6, 36-39]. The solid-state photoluminescence of CPs 1 and 2 was determined at room temperature, as shown in Fig. 9. The fluorescent emission peaks were observed at 468 nm (λex = 360 nm) for CP 1 and 471 nm (λex = 360 nm) for CP 2, respectively. In order to understand the nature of such emission bands, the photoluminescent property of free 4-pytpy ligand was also measured. Upon excitation at 320 nm, the free 4-pytpy ligand shows the fluorescent emission band at 374 nm, which can be assigned to the π* → π or n → π* electronic transitions (Fig. S4, Supplementary Material). In comparison with that of free 4-pytpy ligands, the observed red-shift of the emissions is probably caused by the collaborative effects of intra-ligand emission and ligand-to-metal charge transition (LMCT) [40]. The differences in the band positions of CPs 1 and 2 might be related to the differences in the metal centers and coordination environments or the degree of π-electron overlap of the multitopic organic linkers in these structures [41]. The intensity differences between CPs 1 and 2 may be ascribed to the different conjugation effect of 4-pytpy and M atom in CPs 1 and 2 [42].

The addition of [Ni(4-pytpy)2](NO3)2 (0.05 mmol, 0.0402 g) in 2 mL DMSO solution resulted in a light yellow solution. After stirring and subsequent filtration, a solution of DMSO (3 mL) was layered gently on the top of the filtrate. After that, a solution of CuN(CN)2 (0.2 mmol,0.0261 g) and NaN(CN)2 (0.2 mmol,0.0178 g) dissolved in 2 mL DMF/CH3CN (v/v = 1:1) was successively laid carefully as the third layer. The resulting solution was allowed to diffuse slowly in the dark. After 1 week, orange needle crystals of CP 1 were obtained for single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. Yield: 0.035 g, 59.3 %. Anal. Calc. for C99H77Cu4N39Ni2O9S (%): C, 50.32; H, 3.26; N, 23.13; Found: C, 50.28; H, 3.25; N, 23.15. IR for CP 1 (KBr pellets, cm−1): 3456(m), 3065(m), 2364(m), 1609(s), 1492(m), 1385(vs), 1016(m), 809(m).

cln_elements.content:
Thermal properties of CPs 1 and 2 were evaluated by thermogravimetric analysis under the N2 atmosphere from 25 to 1200 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min. It is worth noting that the structure of CP 1 begins to collapse after about 360 °C, while the network of CP 2 begins to collapse at around 300 °C. This thermal behavior of CPs 1 and 2 is in sharp contrast to that of monometallic CPs based on 4-pytpy ligand, which usually starts to collapse near 180 °C [29].

As described in Fig. 8, the TGA curve of CP 1 can be divided into three stages. The first weight loss of 8.61 % occurs in 95–219 °C, corresponding to the liberation of free H2O molecules, DMF and volatiles of NO3– (NO2, O2) (calculated: 3.05 % for H2O, 3.09 % for DMF and 2.63 % for NO2, O2) [32–35]. In the temperature of 341–359 °C, the second weight loss of 3.36 % is in accordance with the loss of DMSO molecules (calculated: 3.31 %). With the increase in temperature, the dicyanamide and 4-pytpy ligand begin to decompose, and the structure of CP 1 begins to collapse [35]. For CP 2, the structure is stable up to about 300 °C, followed by the weight loss of 21.13 %, which is consistent with the decomposition of four dicyanamide (calculated: 20.92 % for four dicyanamide) [35]. As the temperature increases, the 4-pytpy ligand and the rest of dicyanamide begin to decompose and the network of CP 2 continues to collapse.

Luminescent Properties

It is well-documented that CPs, especially with d10 metal centers and conjugated organic ligands, have been investigated for photoluminescent properties because of their potential applications as luminescent materials [6, 36–39]. The solid-state photoluminescence of CPs 1 and 2 was determined at room temperature, as shown in Fig. 9. The fluorescent emission peaks were observed at 468 nm (λex = 360 nm) for CP 1 and 471 nm (λex = 360 nm) for CP 2, respectively. In order to understand the nature of such emission bands, the photoluminescent property of free 4-pytpy ligand was also measured. Upon excitation at 320 nm, the free 4-pytpy ligand shows the fluorescent emission band at 374 nm, which can be assigned to the π* → π or n → π* electronic transitions (Fig. S4, Supplementary Material). In comparison with that of free 4-pytpy ligands, the observed red-shift of the emissions is probably caused by the collaborative effects of intra-ligand emission and ligand-to-metal charge transition (LMCT) [40]. The differences in the band positions of CPs 1 and 2 might be related to the differences in the metal centers and coordination environments or the degree of π-electron overlap of the multitopic organic linkers in these structures [41]. The intensity differences between CPs 1 and 2 may be ascribed to the different conjugation effect of 4-pytpy and M atom in CPs 1 and 2 [42].

Conclusions

In summary, two interesting heterobimetallic CPs have been synthesized under the assistance of the metalloligands [M(4-pytpy)2](NO3)2 (M=Ni, Co) and auxiliary ligand [N(CN)2]−. Structural analysis demonstrates that CP 1 exhibits a 1D double chain structure, while CP 2 possesses a unique 2D network skeleton. Thermal analysis reveals that the structure of CP 1 begins to collapse after about 360 °C, while CP 2 can be stable up to 300 °C. In addition, solid-state luminescence properties of CPs 1 and 2 were also investigated. The emission are red-shift for both CPs 1 and 2 in contrast to that of 4-pytpy ligand. Further studies on the design and syntheses of metalloligand-based heterobimetallic CPs with unique molecular configurations and strong luminescence properties are currently in progress.
